#**Cooking Recipe**
## *Baked Alaska*
![Baked Alaska](data:image/jpeg;base64,)


###List of Ingredients  

    * 6 cups ice cream, one flavor or a mix of them
    * 3 ounces (85 grams) unsweetened chocolate, roughly chopped
    * 1 stick (4 ounces or 115 grams) unsalted butter, plus extra for pan
    * 1 1/3 cups (265 grams) granulated sugar
    * 2 large eggs
    * 1 teaspoon (5 ml) vanilla extract
    * 1/2 teaspoon flaky sea salt or 1/4 teaspoon table salt (about 2 grams)
    * 2/3 cup (85 grams) all-purpose flour
    * 3 large egg whites
    * Pinch of cream of tartar
###Special Kitchen Tools Required

    * Electric Mixer
    * Blowtorch
    * Heatproof Bowls
    * Parchment Paper
###Steps

    1. Coat a 1.5 quart bowl lightly with nonstick spray.
    2. Scoop ice cream into bowl using the overhang to cover exposed ice cream and press it mostly flat.
    3. Leave ice cream in freezer overnight until fully firm
    4. Make the brownie base by heating oven to 350 degrees Fahrenheit.
    5. Line a baking pan (larger than ice cream bowl) with parchment paper and butter the parchment.
    6. Melt chocolate and butter together, whisk in sugar, eggs, vanilla, and salt.
    7. Bake for 25-30 minutes.
    8. Let cool in pan on a rack for 15 minutes.
    9. Beat the egg whites with cream of tartar in an electric mixer and then beat in the sugar a spoonful at a time. Keep running the mixer until the meringue is stiff and shiny.
    10. Beat in more salt and vanilla.
    11. Frost the brownie and let it sit in freezer for an hour.
    12. Blowtorch the cake until toasted all over.

[Baked Alaska](https://smittenkitchen.com/2016/09/baked-alaska-smitten-kitchen-turns-10/) is perfect for birthday parties and warm summer days by the pool.Probably too cold to eat when in [Alaska](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alaska).
    
The total listed time is *24 hours* (with one hour of hands-on preparation) but that can be reduced to 8 hours by keeping it in the freezer for less time.

Instead of torching the meringue in Step 12, one can simply preheat the oven to 500 degrees Fahrenheit to get the same toasting effect.
    
#Wikipedia

###Definiton [edit](no need to include hyperlink .example.com) 
The **Eucledian distance** between points **p** and **q** is the length of the [line segment](no need to include hyperlink.example.com) connecting them $(\overline {\textbf {pq}})$.

In [Cartesian coordinates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cartesian_coordinate_system), if $\textbf p = (p_1, p_2,..., p_n)$ and $\textbf q = (q_1, q_2, ..., q_n)$ are two points in [Euclidean *n*-space](don't include hyperlink) then the distance (d) from **p** to **q**, or from **q** to **p** is given by the [Pythagorean formula](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pythagorean_theorem).


  $\textit d(\textbf p, \textbf q) = \textit d(\textbf q, \textbf p)= \sqrt{(q_1 - p_1)^2 + (q_2 - p_2)^2 + ... + (q_n - p_n)^2}$

  $$=\sqrt{\sum^n_{i=1}(q_i-p_i)^2 }$$.

The position  of a point in a Euclidean *n*-space is a [Euclidian vector](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euclidean_vector). So, **p** and **q** may be represented as Euclidean vectors, starting from the origin of the space (initial point) with their tips (terminal points) ending at the two points. The [**Euclidean norm**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norm_(mathematics)#Euclidean_norm) or **Euclidean length** or **magnitude** of a vector measures the length of the vector.

 $\parallel \textbf p \parallel  = \sqrt{p^2_1 + p^2_2 + ... + p^2_n} = \sqrt{\textbf p \cdot \textbf p}$ 
 
where the last expression involves the [dot product](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dot_product)
